dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, we always talk about the climate crisis, right? And, um, greenhouse gases are still rising, like, faster than ever. It's a huge problem.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, we always talk about the climate crisis, right? And, um, greenhouse gases are still rising, like, faster than ever. It's a huge problem.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Despite the existential threat posed by rising atmospheric concentrations of GHGs, emissions continue to increase at a faster pace than previously anticipated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, no kidding. The existential threat is real. But, you know, there's actually a bit of a silver lining, surprisingly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, no kidding. The existential threat is real. But, you know, there's actually a bit of a silver lining, surprisingly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally! That's what caught my eye. Progress in clean energy has actually exceeded expectations. Think EVs, solar, wind... it's all accelerating.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally! That's what caught my eye. Progress in clean energy has actually exceeded expectations. Think E V s, solar, wind... it's all accelerating.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On one front, however, progress in the fight against climate change has exceeded expectations. Amid the global shift from internal combustion engines to electric vehicles (EVs) and the accelerated adoption of solar and wind power, demand for renewable energy is rapidly increasing in the US and the European Union.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Like, demand is through the roof, especially in the US and EU. And a big part of that is prices just plummeting for solar panels, wind turbines, batteries...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Like, demand is through the roof, especially in the U S and E U. And a big part of that is prices just plummeting for solar panels, wind turbines, batteries...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This increased demand has been fueled by significant declines in the real prices of solar panels, wind turbines, batteries, and EVs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and some of that, uh, in the US, is thanks to things like the Inflation Reduction Act, you know, those clean-energy subsidies. But, honestly? A much bigger driver has been those super low-cost Chinese imports.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and some of that, uh, in the U S, is thanks to things like the Inflation Reduction Act, you know, those clean-energy subsidies. But, honestly? A much bigger driver has been those super low-cost Chinese imports.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the US, this can be attributed in part to the clean-energy subsidies included in President Joe Bidens Inflation Reduction Act and, more significantly, to low-cost Chinese imports.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which brings us to the really alarming part, doesn't it? Because now, like, the US and the EU are slapping all these new tariffs on those very same imports.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which brings us to the really alarming part, doesn't it? Because now, like, the U S and the E U are slapping all these new tariffs on those very same imports.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alarmingly, new tariffs imposed by the US and the EU on imports of solar panels, EVs, and other equipment, threaten to derail this progress.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! It's like, just when things are finally moving, suddenly there's this huge threat to derail everything. I mean, the US just slapped a *hundred percent* tariff on Chinese EVs!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! It's like, just when things are finally moving, suddenly there's this huge threat to derail everything. I mean, the U S just slapped a hundred percent tariff on Chinese E V s!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In May, the Biden administration imposed a 100% tariff on Chinese EVs, along with new levies on a range of other Chinese goods, including solar cells and lithium-ion batteries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the EU, um, they've got provisional tariffs too, after their investigation. It's, like, what's the goal here? Protecting domestic industries? Claims of unfair subsidies?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the E U, um, they've got provisional tariffs too, after their investigation. It's, like, what's the goal here? Protecting domestic industries? Claims of unfair subsidies?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Meanwhile, the European Commission has imposed provisional tariffs on Chinese EVs after an eight-month investigation found that Chinas unfair subsidization of its EV industry undercuts EU competitors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, yeah, that's what they say. To protect American workers, our industries. But it completely undermines their own climate goals, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, yeah, that's what they say. To protect American workers, our industries. But it completely undermines their own climate goals, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These measures aim to protect American workers and critical domestic industries. But they risk undermining the administrations climate agenda, particularly its efforts to raise the share of renewables to 100% of US electricity by 2035 and the share of EVs to 50% of new car sales by 2030.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's so contradictory! We're telling China to, like, pay its fair share for the energy transition, but then we're blocking their cheapest tech that would help us achieve it. It makes zero sense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's so contradictory! We're telling China to, like, pay its fair share for the energy transition, but then we're blocking their cheapest tech that would help us achieve it. It makes zero sense.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Western countries have demanded that China pay its fair share of these costs, but their own trade policies are starkly at odds with their objectives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And economically, it's just, uh, a mess. Sure, maybe you create some jobs in solar panel manufacturing, but then you lose jobs in the installation sector that relies on those cheap panels.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And economically, it's just, uh, a mess. Sure, maybe you create some jobs in solar panel manufacturing, but then you lose jobs in the installation sector that relies on those cheap panels.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although US tariffs may help create jobs in the solar-panel industry, those would be offset by job losses in the solar-energy installation sector, which relies on low-cost equipment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, higher prices for consumers, right? I mean, tariffs on batteries mean more expensive EVs. And with inflation being such a big concern right now...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, higher prices for consumers, right? I mean, tariffs on batteries mean more expensive E V s. And with inflation being such a big concern right now...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Similarly, some EV production jobs would disappear if tariffs led to higher prices for battery imports. Meanwhile, many export jobs would be cut when China and other countries inevitably retaliate against Western restrictions. With US unemployment at 4%, policymakers and voters are currently more concerned about inflation than jobs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, the article points out, policymakers and voters are often more worried about inflation than jobs at this moment. So, removing tariffs would actually *lower* energy and transport costs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, the article points out, policymakers and voters are often more worried about inflation than jobs at this moment. So, removing tariffs would actually lower energy and transport costs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With US unemployment at 4%, policymakers and voters are currently more concerned about inflation than jobs. Removing tariffs is the surest way for Western governments to lower energy and transportation prices, thereby reducing inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's like, if we truly want to fight climate change efficiently and affordably, we should be embracing international trade, not putting up barriers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's like, if we truly want to fight climate change efficiently and affordably, we should be embracing international trade, not putting up barriers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is yet another example of how international trade could lower the costs of the clean-energy transition if we were to embrace it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Not, uh, shooting ourselves in the foot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not, uh, shooting ourselves in the foot.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. It's a really complex picture, but the economics seem pretty clear on this one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. It's a really complex picture, but the economics seem pretty clear on this one.
